attributes.alt: Book cover for How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague. The cover shows a dinosaur with his giant foot on a child's bicycle, riding clumsily down a street while an excited woman watches him.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary
Begin Circle Time by introducing the book and asking:
How can you stay safe at home?
Read for enjoyment and entertainment, noticing vocabulary in context
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use top-to-bottom and left-to-right directionality when writing.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Challenge children to talk about pictures that show ways to keep safe.
Guide children to ask and answer questions about things people can do to stay safe.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Can you find of characters in the book who are doing things that are safe?
Can you pretend to be a dinosaur? How would you move?
How would you sort the dinosaurs into different groups?
Can you write about one way you can stay safe?
Can you build a dinosaur? What materials would you use?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
? Can you think of another word that starts with that sound?
Can you build a safe place for a dinosaur to live? What kind of place will it be?

attributes.alt: Book cover for How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague. The cover shows a dinosaur with his giant foot on a child's bicycle, riding clumsily down a street while an excited woman watches him.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Help children talk about feelings and how they can identify different feelings in others.
Guide children to look at  facial expressions and posture to sort photos into groups that show happy and unhappy people.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Can you show me pictures of characters who are happy? Can you find characters who are sad?
Can you act out how to keep someone safe?
Can you put three characters in the book in order from biggest   to smallest?
Have you ever made someone feel better when they were sad?
Can you draw a picture of a happy person?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the end of the word
? Can you think of another word that starts with that letter?
Can you build a place where you would take a friend to cheer  them up?

attributes.alt: Book cover for How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague. The cover shows a dinosaur with his giant foot on a child's bicycle, riding clumsily down a street while an excited woman watches him.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share comprehension skill
Begin Story Time by revisiting the Big Book, and asking the guiding question:
What are some ways to stay safe outside?
Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement; Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Remove word from a compound word.
Help children look at pictures and determine whether the safe activity is inside or outside.
Talk about what makes each activity safe.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Can you find pictures of children doing things outside while being safe? How do you know they are being safe?
Pretend you are climbing the biggest tree in the world.
What could you use to measure your head?
Write how you could stay safe in a new place.
Can you draw a picture of a friend wearing a helmet?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Build a tall tower. What materials would you use?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Five Little Froggies Jumping on a Bed. There are six pictures of frogs on a bed. The captions explain each picture: Five little froggies jumping on a bed; Four little froggies jumping on a bed; Three little froggies jumping on a bed; Two little froggies jumping on a bed; One little froggy jumping on a bed; and, finally, Mom comes in and says "No more froggies jumping on the bed."

elements.text: Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed

attributes.alt: Book cover for How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague. The cover shows a dinosaur with his giant foot on a child's bicycle, riding clumsily down a street while an excited woman watches him.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about health and safety and to try out different ways to jump.
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed
Read interactively and connect to this weekâ€™s concept question,
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Help children look at pictures and determine whether the activity is safe or not safe.
Talk about what makes each activity safe or not safe.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
How can you stay safe when you are riding a bike?
Pretend to be one of the froggies in the Big Chart. What will you wear?
Can you use counters to count the number of froggies you see in each picture in the Big Chart?
Can you write about how you can stay safer on the playground?
What would be a safe place for people to jump? Can you draw it?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build two climbing walls? What materials would you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to play a game to reinforce listening skills and to introduce vocabulary
What did you learn from  the dinosaurs about staying safe?
Show background knowledge; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use subject-verb agreement; Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Use top-to-bottom and left-to-right directionality when writing.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Support children as they independently respond to this weekâ€™s prompt:
Why is it important to keep safe while you play?
Save childrenâ€™s writing to display next week.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?
Can you find pictures of children helping each other stay safe?
Imagine you are in a car ride. What can you do to stay safe?
Use counters to count how many children are wearing blue.
Can you write about something that you do at home to stay safe?
Can you draw a picture of a friend wearing a seatbelt?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
? Can you think of another word that makes that sound?
Can you create a place for you and a friend to play?
